If you are bringing unit testing into an existing dev/QA structure, you
want the tests written by the two groups to start to diverge, you want a
clear demarcation point between the two roles, and you want good
communication across that boundary.

The developers write their unit tests. The unit tests are designed to be
as simple as possible and have the widest coverage possible. The
developers run these tests in their own sandbox. It doesn't make much
sense to automate the reporting of bugs here, since the failures are in
code in the sandbox, not in the repository. When the tests pass in the
sandbox, the next step is to update the sandbox from the repository to
integrate any recent changes made by other developers (easy to do using
CVS or BitKeeper). Then, if the tests still pass, the changes are
comitted back to the repository.

In most XP groups, there is a periodic integration test on an integration
workstation. This workstation is supposed to have a clean configuration at
all times (It may be reimaged frequently). Someone does a clean checkout
to this machine and runs the tests to verify that everything is integrating
correctly in that environment. This is done one or two times a day.

In a group with a slightly heavier weight process, the integration may be
run by QA folks. The QA folks use the unit tests to verify a clean build
before taking the snapshot to their side for further (functional) testing.
This is where it may make sense to enter failures into bug tracking, but
failures should be rare and will always require some immediate
investigation. I'm not sure that automation will buy one much over just
entering the bug report by hand.

This is also a good place to run any coverage analysis tools and look for
trouble spots. If the QA group does this, it will probably satisfy their
desire for oversite of the developers' process. Be careful with coverage
analysis, though- use it to identify serious weakpoints but don't become a
slave to metrics. Even the best analysis tools will miss branches which
have been taken in tests but whose results were never verified or will
identify assertions or roadblocks as "uncovered code". It's also OK to not
have 100% (branch/statement/expression) coverage all the time. Coverage
should steadily approach 100% over the life of the project as refactoring
occurs and tests are added to reproduce reported bugs.

The QA folks then perform their testing, concentrating on the functional
side. In some cases, particularly with public APIs, JUnit can be useful to
them as well, but higher level scripting tools tend to be more useful.
Something like Jython or NetRexx can be mixed with JUnit to give
the best of both. I have found that it is best if most of the QA group
has basic scripting skills. There should be one QA toolsmith per group (or
shared with at most three small QA groups) who can do the heavyweight
programming needed to create specialized test tools for the rest of the
group. Again, though, I'm not sure I see where integration with JUnit will
buy you much. In large projects, I've sometimes wanted an analysis tool
which would check a database and verify that the test suite only reported
expected failures (i.e. those for known, active defects) and all of the
expected failures, but I've never wanted anything to report defects for
me. There is too much value in a well-written defect report. Check Brian
Marrick's site (http://www.testing.com/) for good articles on how to
improve defect reports. You would also have to figure out how to avoid the
phenomenon of cascading failures- one defect at a sufficiently low level
can cause hundreds of testcase failures. One doesn't want to bury the
developers in hundreds of automated defects. This can be attenuated if
your bug tracking system  is aware of test or component interdependencies,
but it takes a lot of extra work for the small automation gain.

On Mon, 19 Nov 2001, Alan Pearlman Spencer wrote:

> Thanks,
> I agree with the idea about "if you are doing it properly you don't
> need this"...
> I'm trying to migrate a dev/QA team over to the "right" way and I
> suppose
> the QA team are scared about loosing visibility into the tests (that are
> written by the developers).
>
> We will have nightly builds and they will run the tests and I suppose
> they want to be able to get some visibility into the fixing of these
> problems. There is a fair argument that they don't need to know, that
> is the beauty...
> Thanks for the long response!
> Alan.

>
> Forgive me, but isn't this rather contrary to the spirit of JUnit and
> its
> TestInfected/XP approach?  Kent says we're supposed to cycle through the
> testing and coding stages a few times until our code has no bugs.  So
> what
> is there to track?  same goes for integration: providing we're
> developing in
> small enough chunks, of course.
>
> Or look at it another way: our failed tests are their own bug
> trackingdevice.
>
> Automatically populating a bug track database from failed tests would
> only
> make sense when the people running the tests aren't the same people who
> are
> developing the code, for instance users in UAT or a "black box" testing
> cell.  I don't think JUnit is sufficiently abstract for the former but I
> can
> see that the latter could be writing their own JUnit suites (if they
> know
> Java).  In which case your question is simply a variant on the "How do I
> log
> output from JUnit?" question, only instead of writing to a logfile you
> want
> to insert the results into an error tracking database.  How difficult
> that
> is depends on the database in question: if it's something proprietary
> like
> Merant Tracker I imagine there'll be a few more problems than if (like
> us)
> you're using a homebrew system based on tables sitting in your
> development
> Oracle DB.  The Bugzilla FAQ does say we write to the database using the
> Mozilla XML API so it would be possible to do, but I think you'll be
> lucky
> to find anyone who's actually done it :P
>
> rgds, APC
